items.subjectRaw: “Getting High in Siberia” - C.H.A.M.P.’s 1st Film and Lecture, hosted by BosLabs
items.subject: “Getting High in Siberia” - C.H.A.M.P.’s 1st Film and Lecture, hosted by BosLabs
items.htmlBody:
“Getting High in Siberia”

  • C.H.A.M.P.’s 1st Film and Lecture, hosted by BosLabs


Sunday, March 8th

4 pm


101 South Street

Somerville, Boynton Yards

First floor


Tickets: $8: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/getting-high-in-siberia-tickets-1982736069959?aff=oddtdtcreato


Author, explorer, and mycologist Lawrence Millman, Ph.D.,

describes the ritual use of the wapak (Amanita muscaria) and introduces Pegtymel (2000; runtime 32 min), a documentary on the indigenous peoples of Siberia and their relationship to this hallucinogenic mushroom. Description below.



"Pegtymel [Filmed and Produced by Andrei Golovnev] is a visual poem on the summer life of a reindeer-breeding Chukchi group. With stunning sensitivity and ethnographic intelligence the author photographs mostly camp activities. Against this background unfolds a tale of visions induced by the hallucinogenic fly agaric, mirrored also in old petroglyphs. Assembled together in a coherent mosaic structure, the visual materials give the impression of a cultural whole, of a global cultural form. A rare achievement indeed."
- Asen Balikci, Anthropology Today (December 2000)



The film depicts Chukchi reindeer herders everyday life on the Pegtymel River, on the coast of the Chukchi Sea in the northeast part of Russia. Daily life and the autumn ritual are intersected with fly agaric mushroom stories told by old man Natalko and rock art images painted a thousand years ago on the Pegtymel cliffs. The camera traces the vivid dialogue of ancient and current traditions, beliefs and rituals, humans and nature; these are impressively abundant and picturesque in Chukchi traditional culture today.


About the speaker:

Larry Millman (https://lawrencemillman.com) has made over 40 trips and expeditions to the Arctic and Subarctic. The photo shows him in a contemplative mood on a beach in Siberia.





Sent with Proton Mail secure email.

items.subject: C.H.A.M.P. Admin Meeting: 2/23/2026 @ 5:30 pm @ Belmont Public Library
items.htmlBody:
Hello, Everyone!


On Monday, February 23 @ 5:30 pm we are meeting at the Belmont Public Library to discuss our goals as a community of mushroom lovers dedicated to science, art, and public outreach pertaining to fungi!


Please join us!  


2/23/2026 @ 5:30-7:30pm!


C.H.A.M.P. Admin Meeting

Belmont Public Library

336 Concord Ave.

Belmont, MA



Sent with Proton Mail secure email.

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: Members in the News] Larry Millman on GBH Morning Edition (1.15.26)
items.subject: Larry Millman on GBH Morning Edition (1.15.26)
items.htmlBody:
On the radio: Mycologist Larry Millman is on a mission to record the fungi at Fresh Pond Reservation in Cambridge. He’s one discovery away from cataloging his 400th species. Listen to this charismatic champion of uncharismatic fungi: 


https://www.wgbh.org/news/local/2026-01-15/399-and-counting-one-mans-quest-to-find-fresh-ponds-fungi

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.htmlBody:
﻿Hello mushroom lovers,

We had a marvelous tour of BOSLab, the country’s first community biolab. C.H.A.M.P. members learned about opportunities for using equipment such as PCR thermal cyclers, fluorescence plate readers, incubators, and autoclaves. We discussed the possibilities for DNA barcoding/IT tagging, advanced microscopy, and a range of other art and bio-engineering projects.

We also explored creating C.H.A.M.P. / BOSLab co-branded workshops, including sessions on cultivating mushrooms, hosting a crash course on microscopy and staining, and presenting talks and film screenings.

Lastly, we touched on outdoor programming such as using “Lil Lab”—a laboratory on wheels for conducting science au plein air!

If any of this excites you, send your thoughts to the C.H.A.M.P. suggestion box!

https://comm-hub-myco.github.io/champ-site/

Dr. Wendy Pouliot, neurobiologist and BOSLab President, with the 1940s windshield-wiper display cabinet she converted into “Lil Lab,” a mobile research station outfitted with a trinocular stereo microscope. Underwritten by grants from the Massachusetts Cultural Council.

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] Friday Field Trip (1/9); virtual event tonight
items.subject: Friday Field Trip (1/9); virtual event tonight
items.htmlBody:
Hello Mushroom Lover!

I’m excited to invite you to an in-person, on-site visit to BOSLabs (https://www.boslab.org/projects), a nonprofit community laboratory that makes cutting-edge biology hands-on and accessible to curious people outside traditional academia. If you’re interested in fungi, this is a rare chance to see how tools like DNA sequencing, yeast engineering, imaging, and biochemistry can be used to identify, grow, study, and even design biological systems—sometimes in delightfully unexpected ways (they’ve even experimented with synthesizing truffle flavor in a lab). BOSLabs supports open, lay science: teaching, experimentation, and creative exploration across biology, chemistry, genetics, and bioengineering.


The on-site visit will take place on Friday, January 9, between noon and 7 pm (time to be determined). There will also be a virtual online open house happening tonight at 7 PM. RSVP here for virtual open house:


https://meetu.ps/e/PzDLC/B3jBy/i


If you’re interested in the in-person visit, please email me with the times you’d be available this Friday between noon and 7 pm, and I’ll confirm the time that works for the greatest number of people.


Thx,

Jon Applefield

items.subject: Ari - Project Idea
items.htmlBody:
Happy New Year to all 🥂🍾🍄
Here is a description of a possible project that CHAMP can take on. 
This is just an outline. It does not include technicalities. I can provide the technical methodology if a consensus is reached. 
The project entails placing a network of synchronized (programmable) LED lights under the surface of water. For example, “Duckpond”, at Boston Public Garden, this is where the Swan boats are. In the winter the pond is un-utilized. Procedurally, the LED-network will be installed in the pond before it freezes. When the pond does eventually freeze over, it will create the proper conditions to deliver an immersive, colorful light show, with images that appear emanating through the ice. The subject matter can widely vary, and include fungi with associated culturally-themed characters. This can also be set to sound affects. Funding for the project can be through the Mass Cultural Council. Or, directly from the city of Boston Art Commission.

                         Ari 

                Ari Stamatiou 
         Plimira@comcast.net
                617-962-8550

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] C.H.A.M.P.’s Weekend Update; Forecasting Next Events
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P.’s Weekend Update; Forecasting Next Events
items.htmlBody:
Report from C.H.A.M.P.’s 1st Foray, Lincoln, MA 12.7.25 

Larry started off saying something about the importance of noticing what we don’t see, but the presence of negative data couldn’t hold a candle to what materialized 10 minutes later: Bulgaria inquinans, commonly called Black Bulgar or Bachelor’s Buttons – bulbous protrusions like gobs of tar emerging from huge sawn logs – oak, I believe. Matte black, like Finnish licorice, with cup-like depressions. I mistakenly thought the name had something to do with the former Soviet country, Bulgaria, but etymology filled the binomial with color and motion: “inflated,” “blister-like;” “dirtying,” “polluting,” “blackening,” “staining,” “making unclean.” So be it -  the dirty, bulging fungi left me feeling renewed. Larry’s words and our presence as a group in the woods – Jula, his Dad, Martin, and son Micha; Dan, Liam, Sean, KieuLy, Larry, and myself – amplified a simple message: even on a chilly, steel-grey New England morning, the forest floor holds a cache of little treasures – like Hanukkah gelt or Christmas cookies – cups, crusts, and jellies, resplendent in a quiet but full-throated way, edging out the inelegant rumble of the MBTA commuter rail trundling by. Arboreal chamber music enjoyed from front-row seats, reminding me of John Cage, amateur mycologist and vanguard creator of aleatory music: “There is no such thing as an empty space or an empty time. There is always something to see, something to hear. In fact, try as we may to make a silence, we cannot.”

A quick rundown of notable species seen: a cascade of lumpy polypores – Trametes gibbosa; oak-log sections tinted with green wood-staining fungus – Chlorociboria sp.; tiny matchstick fungi – Phaeocalicium polyporaeum – lifting off from the margins of purple-tooth polypores – Trichaptum abietinum; and, as if bidding us farewell like tiny munchkins from Oz, a “hairy fairy” – Lachnum virgineum; and a troupe of Mycena sp.

On the Horizon

Stay tuned for our next events. Plans are underfoot for a movie night pegged to an ethnographic film.

M

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] Reminder: Larry Millman’s walk @ 11 AM Sunday
items.subject: Reminder: Larry Millman’s walk @ 11 AM Sunday
items.htmlBody:
Not all fungi head to Florida for the winter!  RSVP. 

Join Larry Millman @ Codman Woods - Lincoln, MA.  Sunday @ 11:00 AM. Parking at Donelan's Supermarket - 145 Lincoln Road, Lincoln, MA 01773.

C.H.A.M.P. Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion
